name: Matthew Sparrow
position: Stealth Startup contributor. Former software engineer with Google and Starbucks.
about:
Self-motivated engineer with a passion for problem-solving. My previous roles include owning test automation for two large projects at Google, where I developed tests and CICD infrastructure for cutting-edge hardware and cloud-based machine learning projects. 
Previously, I contributed to the End-to-end testing division at Starbucks, developing in-house testing tools and ensuring seamless code integration of incoming changes to the Starbucks app and backend infrastructure. With a strong foundation in C#, Azure, Python, and SQL, I am committed to driving innovation and business value through technology.

Graduated with a BS in computer science from UC San Diego in 2019.

In my free time I like to develop simple games using Unity and Pygames.

name: Jorge Nunez
about:
As a Previous Software Engineering Intern at Qualcomm, I applied my skills and knowledge in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science to create innovative and high-quality software solutions for various products and platforms.

I am also a recent graduate of UC Berkeley with a B.S. in Electrical Engineering and Computer Sciences. I am a previous Research Assistant at the Algorithms and Computing for Education (ACE) Lab, where I developed computer-based testing software for the introductory computer science course, The Beauty and Joy of Computing. This software aims to provide mastery-learning in a stress-free environment and make computer science education more accessible and inclusive for all students. I am passionate about using software to empower people and create a positive social impact.

The program includes the development of a curriculum that allows the students to explore and understand different aspects of the Vietnamese and Vietnamese-American culture. Responsibilities include fundraising, recruiting, outreach, and effective collaboration with a team of 20 other UC‚Ä¶

          As the Co-Director of VISION, I am tasked with the management and planning of a 4-day, 3-night overnight program that hosts over 30 high school students from all over California on the UC Berkeley campus. The program includes the development of a curriculum that allows the students to explore and understand different aspects of the Vietnamese and Vietnamese-American culture. Responsibilities include fundraising, recruiting, outreach, and effective collaboration with a team of 20 other UC Berkeley students. experience.title: Software Engineer
experience.description: I spearheaded the development of a data service platform offering transformative analytics solutions to the Asia-Pacific financial sector. My tasks involved acquiring and processing vast datasets from diverse sources such as sales, imports, and stocks. Utilizing Python, Java Spring Boot, and Ant Design Pro frameworks, I crafted both the frontend and backend software to monitor data collection's progress and status, and to provide analytical insights.My technical contributions encompassed designing RESTful APIs, creating HTTP endpoints for data retrieval from multiple databases, and conducting analyses on inter-database relationships to discern trends and correlations. While this platform was initially conceived for internal applications, there are ongoing discussions to showcase the website and visualizations to external stakeholders.
experience.description_html:
I spearheaded the development of a data service platform offering transformative analytics solutions to the Asia-Pacific financial sector. My tasks involved acquiring and processing vast datasets from diverse sources such as sales, imports, and stocks. Utilizing Python, Java Spring Boot, and Ant Design Pro frameworks, I crafted both the frontend and backend software to monitor data collection's progress and status, and to provide analytical insights.

My technical contributions encompassed designing RESTful APIs, creating HTTP endpoints for data retrieval from multiple databases, and conducting analyses on inter-database relationships to discern trends and correlations. While this platform was initially conceived for internal applications, there are ongoing discussions to showcase the website and visualizations to external stakeholders.

recommendations: Oh Tepmongkol-Wheaton ‚ÄúI was impressed with Scott's dedication to this internship despite his 40 minutes commute each way to our office. He had a good attitude and was willing to work on variety of tasks using C++, CUDA, PHP, MySQL, and Python to help our team collected crucial performance data. It was a pleasure interacting with him this summer. Scott will make a great addition to any team.‚Äù

Kevin Acken ‚ÄúScott worked as a software intern at our company, The OhZone, during the summer of 2019. During his internship, Scott impressed us with his ability to quickly learn and improve upon advanced algorithms and data structures, ability to calculate and compare algorithmic performance optimizations (C++), his willingness and ability to delve into new areas (backend web server, PhP, MySQL), and his effectiveness working both independently and in a team environment. Example tasks that Scott worked on include: (1) stepping through and learning multiple large C++ software packages, adding new optimizations, and completing quality/performance experiments; (2) running output quality experiments based on varying algorithm parameters; (3) co-programmed statistics tabulating web pages using PHP and pulling and manipulating data using MySQL; (4) learning CUDA in an effort to improve program performance. It was a pleasure having Scott work for The OhZone, and we highly recommend him for any future opportunities in technology companies.‚Äù

name: Aviral Mishra
about:
A Computer Science Graduate dedicated to pushing the capabilities of computer science. 

My experiences range throughout all aspects of computer science. I have a particular interest for Machine Learning based applications through my past internship experience at companies like Quantiphi working on Computer Vision Software or my recent experiences with Large Language Models through my current internship at Appsoc. Alongside work experience are the numerous classes I have taken in the field from the math behind machine learning to visualizing neural networks and unmasking the black box. I also have worked on a multitude of personal projects, designing playable opponents in my favorite Board Game Quoridor through reinforcement learning or using natural language processing to build a more secure security scanner.

I am however committed to all aspects of Computer Science including past experiences in Blockchain Development through the start-up I co-founded in highschool and my experience with robotics work in the lab I am currently in. Not to mention my consistent drive to constantly  learn new technologies. This past summer and through this current Fall semester, I have the privilege of working at Appsoc, a cybersecurity firm designing DevOps software, granting me new experiences in a field I have not worked in before. With my most recent work experience at Realm Labs, I was able to work in a full stack environment working on a variety of different projects. I worked on high quality data connectors for Sharepoint, OneDrive, Confluence, and DataBricks used for RAG Chatbots. I built a frontend and backend testing suite that was used for 80% of our testing purposes. And worked on a variety of Data Governance and Interpretability tools to provide disclaimers and study the output of chatbots.

My commitment to Computer Science extends to helping others find that same passion and drive. As a current director for Cal Hacks, the largest collegiate Hackathon in the country, I can share my love by running the logistics and entertainment events to make the competition a success for all 2000 participants. Not to mention my tutoring experiences working in small class and one on one tutoring sessions to more directly educate others.

publications.title: New Fusion Algorithm provides an alternative approach for Robotic path planning
publications.subtitle: International Journal of Information Engineering and Electronic Business.
publications.description: üßëüèª‚ÄçüíªFirst Author For rapid growth in technology and automation, human tasks are being taken over by robots as robots have proven to be better with both speed and precision. One of the major and widespread usages of these robots is in the industrial businesses, where they are employed to carry massive loads in and around work areas. As these working environments might not be completely localized and could be dynamically changing, new approaches must be evaluated to guarantee a crash-free way of performing duties. This paper presents a new and efficient fusion algorithm for solving the path planning problem in a custom 2D environment. This fusion algorithm integrates an improved and optimized version of both, A* algorithm and the Artificial potential field method. Firstly, an initial or preliminary path is planned in the environmental model by adopting the A* algorithm. The heuristic function of this A* algorithm is optimized and improved according to the environmental model. This is followed by selecting and saving the key nodes in the initial path. Lastly, on the basis of these saved key nodes, path smoothing is done by artificial potential field method. Our simulation results carried out using Python viz. libraries indicate that the new fusion algorithm is feasible and superior in smoothness performance and can satisfy as a time-efficient and cheaper alternative to conventional A* strategies of path planning.

publications.title: Augmented Random Search for quadcopter control : An alternative to reinforcement learning
publications.subtitle: International Journal of Information Technology and Computer Science (IJITCS) - Mecs press
publications.description: üßëüèª‚ÄçüíªFirst Author Details - Model-based reinforcement learning strategies are believed to exhibit more significant sample complexity than model-free strategies to control dynamical systems, such as quadcopters. This belief that Model-based strategies that involve the use of welltrained neural networks for making such high-level decisions always give better performance can be dispelled by making use of Model-free policy search methods. This paper proposes the use of a model-free random searching strategy, called Augmented Random Search (ARS), which is a better and faster approach of linear policy training for continuous control tasks like controlling a Quadcopter‚Äôs flight. The method achieves state-of-the-art accuracy by eliminating the use of too much data for the training of neural networks that are present in the previous approaches to the task of Quadcopter control. The paper also highlights the performance results of the searching strategy used for this task in a strategically designed task environment with the help of simulations. Reward collection performance over 1000 episodes and agent‚Äôs behavior in flight for augmented random search is compared with that of the behavior for reinforcement learning state-of- the-art algorithm, called Deep Deterministic policy gradient(DDPG) Our simulations and results manifest that a high variability in performance is observed in commonly used strategies for sample efficiency of such tasks but the built policy network of ARS-Quad can react relatively accurately to step response providing a better performing alternative to reinforcement learning strategies.

publications.title: LeCORe : A Framework for modelling Learner's preference
publications.subtitle: Educational Data Mining, 2018: 11th International Conference on Educational Data Mining , Buffalo,NY, United States
publications.description: Co-Authored the paper as a part of my Internship program with Accenture R&D. Details -Learning & development (L&D) is an important strategic factor for sustainable business growth of any organization. L&D has become an integral part of an organization, considering the fast-paced growth of industries. Success of learning and development program depends on how well it identifies the critical skill gaps in its workforce and bridges those gaps by considering individual learner's strengths and aspirations while recommending learning opportunities. Such recommendation requires a rich information about learners and learning opportunities. In this paper, we propose a framework that recommends learning opportunities to learners based on their preferences. We also propose a way to connect users of similar interests on the platform to improve course engagement. We developed a conversational AI agent that assist the learner in their journey. We evaluated our approach on the dataset consisting of 5,000 learners, and 49,202 courses. Our approach performed significantly better than the baseline approach.

name: Tony Di Sera
city: Salt Lake City, Utah, United States
position: Software developer in Gabor Marth's computational biology lab at the University of Utah, specializing in machine learning for precision oncology and data visualization of genomic data.
about:
https://tonydisera.datavizit.org

I work in a computational biology lab where I develop web applications for clinicians to analyze genomic data in precision medicine. In the last five years, my main focus has been real-time genomic analysis and data viz. My current focus is creating machine learning models to predict cancer drug response. 

I have worked as a software developer for 20+ years.  My first job was in Sacramento CA with Intel.  After that, I moved to Salt Lake City Utah.  My first dream job was working on the Human Genome Project in an academic lab at the University of Utah.  Here I could combine my love of biology with my love of software.  Once I got a taste of this, I never looked back.  I spent 10 years working at the Huntsman Cancer Institute, developing a laboratory management system and genomic data repository.  Four years ago, I  joined a computational biology lab at the University of Utah, working on real-time analysis (cloud-based) and web-based visualizations (D3).  This job challenges and rewards me in ways I never imagined.  I work on a multi-disciplinary team with a great group of people.  Working in the lab has allowed me to learn about many fascinating bioinformatics projects ‚Äî problems that demand rigorous statistical approaches, innovative algorithms, and large-scale data processing.  

I just completed my Master's degree in Data Science (MIDS) from UC Berkeley.

experience.title: Student Researcher
experience.description: ‚Ä¢	Created a compiler to enable constant inter-verifier communication for zero knowledge proofs on secret shared data. name: Anya Sengupta
position: Computer Science and Linguistics at UCLA | Exploring Computational Linguistics
about:
I am a junior-standing student at UCLA with a main academic interest in Computer Science (AI/ML). 

More recently, I have started to develop an interest in computational linguistics as it‚Äôs an interdisciplinary study involving both CS and Machine Learning, particularly studying the cognitive aspects of natural languages. I would love to learn how to code applications using NLP and ML. LLMs have also become the backbone of NLP. I am interested in learning how existing LLM‚Äôs can be reused fine tuned and trained for specific use cases.

experience.title: Research Intern
experience.description: The summer entering my senior year, I was fortunate to participate in a research internship at Harvard Institute for Applied Computational Science. I was exposed to machine learning and computer vision tools to analyze real world data. Through these tools like Tensorflow and Keras, I was able to build, train, and evaluate the spin and other parameters of black holes that couldn't have been explored years ago. My biggest challenge was loading the dataset as it is composed of over 70,000 black hole images in the M87 galaxy captured by the Event Horizon Telescope. However, with the mentorship of my professor and research mentor, I was able to create an accurate and precise model with a 0.01 mean squared error. Being exposed to astrophysics and exploring the interdisciplinary application of CS has been fascinating.
experience.description_html: The summer entering my senior year, I was fortunate to participate in a research internship at Harvard Institute for Applied Computational Science. I was exposed to machine learning and computer vision tools to analyze real world data. Through these tools like Tensorflow and Keras, I was able to build, train, and evaluate the spin and other parameters of black holes that couldn't have been explored years ago. My biggest challenge was loading the dataset as it is composed of over 70,000 black hole images in the M87 galaxy captured by the Event Horizon Telescope. However, with the mentorship of my professor and research mentor, I was able to create an accurate and precise model with a 0.01 mean squared error. Being exposed to astrophysics and exploring the interdisciplinary application of CS has been fascinating.
experience.company: Harvard John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences

experience.title: Research Intern
experience.description: In Summer 2021, I interned at Stanford University's School of Earth, Energy and Environmental Sciences department. I conducted a formal internship research report with 2 other interns on creating complex analyses based on paleontological data. Our project was on extinction risk changes through time. We used Machine Learning models and Logistic Regression Analyses to develop a comprehensive understanding of Extinction Risk for Marine Animal Phyla across the Paleozoic. Through R and the Stanford Earth Body Size dataset, we were able to examine extinction risk in relation to the Paleozoic phyla and various biological and ecological traits. We received significant results as our program determined which phyla and biological/ecological traits incited greater extinction risk in each period of the Paleozoic Era.We presented our findings to the Stanford Faculty and showcased our results at the American Geophysical Union conference.
experience.description_html:
In Summer 2021, I interned at Stanford University's School of Earth, Energy and Environmental Sciences department. I conducted a formal internship research report with 2 other interns on creating complex analyses based on paleontological data. Our project was on extinction risk changes through time.
We used Machine Learning models and Logistic Regression Analyses to develop a comprehensive understanding of Extinction Risk for Marine Animal Phyla across the Paleozoic.

Through R and the Stanford Earth Body Size dataset, we were able to examine extinction risk in relation to the Paleozoic phyla and various biological and ecological traits. We received significant results as our program determined which phyla and biological/ecological traits incited greater extinction risk in each period of the Paleozoic Era.

We presented our findings to the Stanford Faculty and showcased our results at the American Geophysical Union conference.

recommendations: Pedro Monarrez ‚ÄúAnya has a strong interest in combining quantitative and coding skills with the environmental sciences and sustainability, and this is reflected in her professional aspirations. Anya has participated in various research programs for high schoolers to develop and enhance her coding and research skills that she plans to apply and further develop as a college student. These experiences include participating as an intern for CareFall Monitoring Entrepreneurship Project where she helped developed an affordable wearable device for the elderly that detects falls and send alerts. During her internship at Stanford, Anya and her team used the statistical language, R, to develop a machine-learning algorithm to help identify the most important predictors of extinction marine fossil animal groups in the fossil record. They would go on to present the results of their research at the 2022 American Geophysical Union Fall meeting. Given Anya's experience and interests in combining her coding and quantitative skills on environmental and sustainability efforts, and her drive and passions, she would have no problem accomplishing any goals and completing any challenge ahead of her.‚Äù

Jayeeta Chowdhury ‚ÄúAnya Sengupta is a brilliant and exceptional young student. Her strength lies in her focus, diligence, going into depth, eye for details and ability to multi-task. She is compassionate and that helps her to conceive of ideas and projects around technology for better social and health outcomes. She is open to feedback, a fast learner, and able to connect complex factors in solving problems. Anya is an asset and as her mentor, it was a joy to guide her. It was enriching to engage with her and I learnt along the way. Above all, she is a fine human being. I highly recommend Anya for her quality of work, problem solving attitude, hard efforts and the equanimity she demonstrate during high pressure situations. A dynamic academic and entrepreneurial environment will bring out the best in her and shape her extremely well for the future. I wish Anya success and joy in her future endeavours.‚Äù

publications.title: Artificial Intelligence Against Climate Change
publications.subtitle: Springer
publications.description: The industrial, transportation, and residential sectors draw the most energy in the United States. With most energy created by burning fossil fuels, a highly inefficient method of energy creation, global greenhouse gas levels are rising, raising the temperature of the earth, causing natural processes to become unbalanced. The health of the earth is declining. The rise of technology and persisting growth of computing devices known as the Internet of Things (IoT) and increasing automation of systems through Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) is a factor of energy expenditure as more humans desire devices and more systems are built. The ethical implications of utilizing new technology should be evaluated before creating more. This paper explores modern computing systems in the sectors that draw the most energy, and, more specifically, the role AI and IoT play in them. Each sector may become more energy efficient, productive, and safer by introducing edge computing through IoT devices and coupling it with AI computing abilities that already automate most processes. Multiple studies show energy consumption and costs are lowered when edge computing is paired with the IoT and AI. There is less human involvement, more regularity in execution and performance, and more widespread use because of the accessibility. This creates safer, cheaper, energy-efficient systems that utilize existing technology. The ethical implications of these systems are much more positive than what already exists. Coupling the power of AI with the IoT will reduce energy expenditure in modern systems and create a more sustainable world.

experience.title: Student of MIT Online Science, Technology, and Engineer Community Class of 2019
experience.description: MOSTEC is a six-month enrichment program for rising high school seniors across the country who demonstrate a strong academic record and interest in science and engineering. The MOSTEC program consists of 3 phases: academic, conference, and enrichment. During the academic phase, I took a machine learning class where my partner and I built a machine learning model for a Google Play App Store Apps dataset as well as a physics class. During the conference phase, I had the opportunity to travel to MIT to present my project in machine learning to alumni, employers, and leaders. Lastly, the enrichment phase consisted of webinars with alumni, admissions officers, and researchers, and professionals.

name: Eric Kim
about: I am a machine learning engineer with specific expertise in: deep learning, computer‚Ä¶

publications.title: Improved Support for Machine-Assisted Ballot-Level Audits
publications.subtitle: EVT/WOTE
publications.description: This paper studies how to provide support for ballot-level post-election audits. Informed by our work supporting pilots of these audits in several California counties, we identify gaps in current technology in tools for this task: we need better ways to count voted ballots (from scanned images) without access to scans of blank, unmarked ballots; and we need improvements to existing techniques that help them scale better to large, complex elections. We show how to meet these needs and use our system to successfully process ballots from 11 California counties, in support of the pilot audit program. Our new techniques yield order-of-magnitude speedups compared to the previous system, and enable us to successfully process some elections that would not have reasonably feasible without these techniques.

publications.title: Everything You Wanted to Know about the Kernel Trick (but Were Too Afraid to Ask)
publications.subtitle: Self-Published
publications.description: An explanation of the Kernel Trick, framed in the context of Support Vector Machines (SVMs). We investigate how using a kernel allows a linear SVM to efficiently learn nonlinear decision boundaries.

publications.title: Operator-Assisted Tabulation of Optical Scan Ballots
publications.subtitle: EVT/WOTE
publications.description: Introduces the OpenCount system which, through the interleaving of Computer Vision and operator verification, generates vote tallies of optical scan ballots from an election.

publications.title: An Analysis of Write-in Marks on Optical Scan Ballots
publications.subtitle: EVT/WOTE
publications.description: Developed a system to achieve automatic recognition of write-in marks on marked voter ballots. Evaluated the system on a large-scale election in Leon County, Florida, and studied the kinds of write-in marks that are seen in practice.

projects.title: FourVoices: An automatic music generator for four-part harmonies.

Third year student at UC Berkeley pursuing a Bachelor's degree in Data Science with a passion for leveraging data to drive insights and decision-making. Eager to apply my strong analytical skills, creativity, and meticulous attention to detail to tackle complex data challenges and extract meaningful patterns from large datasets.

Seeking internship and research opportunities to expand my practical skills in areas like machine learning, statistical modeling, data visualization, and data engineering. Quick learner who thrives in collaborative environments and is excited to work with cross-functional teams to solve real-world problems using data-driven approaches.

Outside of coursework, I stay up-to-date on the latest advancements in data science, attending workshops and conferences to learn about emerging tools and techniques. I enjoy participating in data science competitions on platforms like Kaggle, honing my skills in exploratory data analysis, feature engineering, and model selection. Always looking for new opportunities to wrangle data, build predictive models, and communicate insights to stakeholders.

publications.title: LLM-KCI: Leveraging Large Language Models to Identify Programming Knowledge Components

publications.description: We introduce a framework using Large Language Models to automatically identify Knowledge Components from programming assignments. Our framework helps educators align assignments with course objectives.

publications.title: Steering Student Behavior and Performance Toward Success with Mastery Learning through Policy Optimization
publications.subtitle: SIGCSE Virtual 2024: Proceedings of the ACM Special Interest Group on Computer Science Education
publications.description: This paper summarizes a 3-semester experiment for a Berkeley's intro-to-computing course. We sought to optimize student project submission behavior and overall performance within a mastery learning context, through adjustments in policy and messaging. Via iterative refinement, we discovered a 'sweet spot' in our attendance and lateness policies that simultaneously prevented procrastination, allowed for near-perfect mastery, engaged students, and garnered extremely positive feedback.

publications.title: Mastery with Method: Calibrating Policies to Boost Completion and Sentiment in a Computing Course using Mastery Learning
publications.subtitle: SIGCSE 2024: Proceedings of the 55th SIGCSE Technical Symposium on Computer Science Education (SIGCSE‚Äô24), Portland, OR
publications.description: In our introductory computer science course at a large public university, we embarked on a transformative journey inspired by Grading for Equity. Our goal: to accommodate differential learning, allowing students to attain a fixed level of mastery, albeit over a variable timeframe.Our course has six major project assessments that comprise 46% of the overall grade. In Fall 2022 (n=234), despite warnings, we allowed indefinite extensions on projects and observed a drastic downturn in project completion rates relative to previous terms.The Spring 2023 iteration (n=107) aimed to rectify this. Students could acquire two-week (or a single emergency one month) extensions. Further extensions obligated a student-staff interaction during dedicated support hours. Completion rates and lateness improved compared to fall, but were still poor compared to historical data. We also observed heightened stress.Summer 2023 (n=59) presented unique challenges: a smaller cohort, different demographics, and a halved timeframe. Nonetheless, we further refined our approach: 72-hour extensions were auto-approved, with additional time warranting a conversation with staff. Further, we mandated attendance to ensure students stay on-pace with material. The outcomes were stellar: near-perfect project completion rates, reduced lateness, and rejuvenated student sentiments. Fall 2023 (n=214) was our testbed for this strategy in a standard term, and early results showcase markedly better metrics compared to Fall 2022 and Spring 2023.In conclusion, while embracing a flexible, mastery-learning approach is vital to accommodate differential learning, finding a judicious equilibrium between autonomy and structure can be pivotal in navigating academic outcomes and student well-being.

publications.title: The Effect of Messaging on Project Completion Rates in an Introductory Computing Class utilizing Mastery Learning
publications.subtitle: CompEd 2023: Proceedings of the ACM Conference on Global Computing Education Vol 2
publications.description: A comparative analysis of project completion rates in our introductory computing course which uses a mastery-learning pedagogical model ‚Äî¬†accommodating fixed learning with variable time, thus allowing any student to achieve any grade their desire given sufficient time and interest ‚Äî¬†across two semesters with different messaging strategies used to mitigate procrastination.

projects.title: Enigma- Cryptographic System (Java)
projects.description: Created a virtual Enigma machine that used progressive substitution cyphers to encrypt a text file (600 million+ configurations in the standard setup.) Configurations can be changed mid-encryption, allowing segments of the input file to be encrypted using different cryptographic algorithms. Built in Java, the project handles file management, extensive input validation, error correction, and optimized ecryption / decryption.

honors_and_awards.title: Summa cum laude (Highest Distinction)
honors_and_awards.description: "The Honors notation on students‚Äô transcripts is the University's way to denote the highest level of academic achievement. To maintain this standard, no exceptions can be made to any honors policy. There are three levels of honors: Distinction, High Distinction, and Highest Distinction (roughly equivalent to cum laude, magna cum laude, and summa cum laude)." For students graduating in Spring 2024, a GPA of 3.986/4 or higher was required for Highest Distinction.

name: Kushagra Srivastava
about:
As a software engineer at the University of California, Berkeley, pursuing a Bachelors of Science in Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, I am passionate about developing impactful, data-driven solutions. My professional experience encompasses the creation of AI-driven tools at SproutsAI and consulting on scalable web projects through Berkeley‚Äôs Cloud @ Cal club. My expertise lies in full-stack programming, cloud computing, and AI technologies, utilizing tools such as React, AWS, and LLMs.

I have developed notable applications, including JournAI, an AI-powered journaling software, and Memory Recall, a cognitive game designed for individuals affected by dementia. These initiatives showcase my dedication to crafting technology that addresses practical challenges and enhances the well-being of users.

I thrive in collaborative environments, where I can contribute to solving complex problems that intersect software engineering and innovation. I am eager to explore potential opportunities for collaboration and discuss how we can work together to achieve significant advancements.

name: Ishan Dogra
about:
Hello! My name is Ishan Dogra, I am currently a senior at UC Berkeley studying Mechanical Engineering and Electrical Engineering + Computer Science (EECS). I am currently working on the control systems for our autonomous vehicle at Formula Electric, a student-led team that designs and builds electric race cars.

Passionate about the intersection of innovating new technologies and entrepreneurship; I am always open to and looking for opportunities, particularly in the fields of controls and embedded software. 

Feel free to reach out via email at ishandogra@berkeley.edu to talk about basketball, new ideas, and anything in between!

publications.description: Avenue to contribute my perspective on topics I find interesting and foster a meaningful exchange of ideas with people across the community, perhaps to find broader purpose that unites us all. In the current unprecedented environment, where COVID-19 has created new physical boundaries, the Internet has probably become more important than ever, bringing us together virtually. With life at a standstill due to COVID-19, I strongly believe that it is beneficial to talk about the opportunities that are available and possibly inspire people within my community by unveiling the actions young people around us are taking.

recommendations: ‚ÄúI had known Raya since June 2022, when she joined my program. I saw, in-person no less, how passionately she takes her personal growth when she took part in an optional lab we offer, learning to code in Node-RED, a programming tool for wiring together hardware devices, APIs and online services in new and interesting ways, where she build a localized weather dashboard using The Weather Channel API. The same passion shone through when she engaged in other activities in the program, whether it was working for 3-months with another team in IBM building an AI based solution for identity threat detection and response, being part of a Drone Lab team (agile development, iterative programming, pair programming, agile story management, managing GitHub repos etc.) which coded drones to do acrobatics, or being part of a four-person team working on their first Patent Disclosure. No matter what the task, she arrived prepared, and enthusiastic, and had a positive impact on the teams she worked with. I highly recommend Raya!‚Äù Show less

‚ÄúI started working with Raya in 2022 when she offered to take over the admin for some security compliance issues I was dealing with. Such an offer is rare (who wants to do paperwork right?) but Raya just saw something important that wasn't being done as it should be, and did it properly. This exemplifies my experience working with her since then; Raya is smart, driven and willing to get down and do what needs to be done (even if it's tedious!). She is sharp and learns quickly, picking up technology with a speed that astounds; more importantly, Raya has become someone that I trust to always "do the right thing" with security issues, and that is something that I do not say of many. My experience of working with Raya has been extremely positive and I thoroughly recommend her.‚Äù Show less

name: Henry Gardner
about:
My expertise is rooted in innovation and exploration. I am a Founding Machine Learning Engineer working on disruptive GenAI tech. My curiosity to explore transcends the professional domain. Whether embarking on global adventures or furthering academic pursuits, I consistently seek out new horizons. My passion for unraveling the unknown has fueled my problem-solving capability, which I approach with a blend of creativity and efficiency. I am a dedicated computer programmer who thrives on creating projects that stretch the boundaries of knowledge. My previous undertakings have spanned diverse landscapes, including but not limited to, the exploration of exoplanets in deep space and a global analysis of what drives suicide in differing countries. 

Beyond my technical capabilities, I posses a multifaced skill set that accompanies various roles and responsibilities. I have led a variety of graduate and undergraduate courses and even volunteered as a first responder. My background has honed my ability to excel under pressure and communicate effectively, enabling me to efficiently solve and manage challenges that arise in any domain.

Specialties: AWS and cloud-based computing, Python, Java, SQL, C, C++, C#, R, JavaScript, command and control of UAV systems, mathematical and statistical analysis, team-oriented and independent, communication skills, interested in learning new things.

name: Owen Lynch
position: Research Software Engineer at the Topos Institute
about:
I am a mathematician with generalist software engineering expertise.

On the software side, I am especially interested in scientific computing (machine learning/data science) and type theory (proofs of correctness). However, I have been running linux and fooling around with code for 10 years, so I have picked up a lot of miscellaneous knowledge, and would be capable of writing most languages in most positions. My favorite languages are Julia, Haskell, and Rust, and I run emacs with vim keybindings; I think that should tell you a good amount about me.

On the math side, I mainly studied category-theory adjacent fields in my bachelors (graduate classes in Algebra, Algebraic Topology, and Algebraic Geometry), and I did my bachelor's thesis on Applied Category Theory. In my master's I'm working on the applied side, so I'm studying probability and statistics. I hope to bring these two fields together in future research.

experience.title: Co-Funder
experience.description: Developed a multi-tenant platform focusing on creating sales funnels, web pages, and email marketing campaigns tailored for digital marketing agencies, aiming to streamline client management.The project employs a microservices architecture developed in C# with .NET Core. A CI/CD pipeline was set up to automate deployments to a Kubernetes cluster.Key FeaturesFull-stack Development: Oversight of all development aspects, from front-end to database and microservices architecture.Sales Funnels & Email Marketing: Enables startups to design and manage sales funnels and email campaigns.Multi-Tenant Architecture: Built to support multiple clients across various verticals securely and efficiently.Microservices Intercommunication: Utilizes Dapr and RabbitMQ for seamless communication between microservices.Database: Uses PostgreSQL for robust data management and employs Entity Framework for object-relational mapping.Security & API Management: Incorporates JWT for authentication and Ocelot as the API Gateway.Front-end Technologies: Utilizes Vue.js for front-end development, chosen for their ease of integration and robust ecosystems.Containerization & CI/CD: Kubernetes is used for container orchestration, with a CI/CD pipeline for automated deployments.Accomplishments- Successfully led the full-stack development of two complex projects, meeting diverse business needs.- Implemented a robust CI/CD pipeline, streamlining the DevOps process and deployment.- Enabled advanced functionalities such as sales analytics, email marketing, and client management across different industries.- Utilized cutting-edge technologies to build a resilient, scalable, and secure architecture.
experience.description_html:
Developed a multi-tenant platform focusing on creating sales funnels, web pages, and email marketing campaigns tailored for digital marketing agencies, aiming to streamline client management.
The project employs a microservices architecture developed in C# with .NET Core. A CI/CD pipeline was set up to automate deployments to a Kubernetes cluster.

Key Features
Full-stack Development: Oversight of all development aspects, from front-end to database and microservices architecture.
Sales Funnels & Email Marketing: Enables startups to design and manage sales funnels and email campaigns.
Multi-Tenant Architecture: Built to support multiple clients across various verticals securely and efficiently.
Microservices Intercommunication: Utilizes Dapr and RabbitMQ for seamless communication between microservices.
Database: Uses PostgreSQL for robust data management and employs Entity Framework for object-relational mapping.
Security & API Management: Incorporates JWT for authentication and Ocelot as the API Gateway.
Front-end Technologies: Utilizes Vue.js for front-end development, chosen for their ease of integration and robust ecosystems.
Containerization & CI/CD: Kubernetes is used for container orchestration, with a CI/CD pipeline for automated deployments.

Accomplishments
- Successfully led the full-stack development of two complex projects, meeting diverse business needs.
- Implemented a robust CI/CD pipeline, streamlining the DevOps process and deployment.
- Enabled advanced functionalities such as sales analytics, email marketing, and client management across different industries.
- Utilized cutting-edge technologies to build a resilient, scalable, and secure architecture.

experience.title: Senior Software Developer
experience.description: Design, architect frameworks and develop custom softwares for clients as needed, using the follow technologies:- C# with Asp .Net framework using MVC pattern and SQL Server.- Delphi with SQL Server for Desktop Backend applications. My main objective was to reduce the complexity of the legacy softwares writing a dedicated framework to port the legacy projects to recently technologies with a significant lower time with a better quality of the code base using design patterns technics, SOLID and KISS principles.The process of the framework development lead us to the necessity to improve the database structure to increase its quality and readability for better maintenance, with that in mind I've written an software to migrate the structures automatically based on its metadata using dictionary based configurations.
experience.description_html:
Design, architect frameworks and develop custom softwares for clients as needed, using the follow technologies:

- C# with Asp .Net framework using MVC pattern and SQL Server.
- Delphi with SQL Server for Desktop Backend applications.

My main objective was to reduce the complexity of the legacy softwares writing a dedicated framework to port the legacy projects to recently technologies with a significant lower time with a better quality of the code base using design patterns technics, SOLID and KISS principles.

The process of the framework development lead us to the necessity to improve the database structure to increase its quality and readability for better maintenance, with that in mind I've written an software to migrate the structures automatically based on its metadata using dictionary based configurations.

projects.title: WakaTime Delphi Plugin
projects.description: Embarcadero Delphi plugin for automatic time tracking and metrics generated from your programming activity.

projects.title: ERX (ERP for different kinds of industries)
projects.description: ERX is a comprehensive Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) solution tailored for Brazilian companies spanning various industries, including fire fighting equipment management, food, body supplements, copper, aluminum production, and event promotion management. The system seamlessly handles the complete industry lifecycle, from resource acquisition to sales, manufacturing, stock management, invoicing, and delivery. It aids in efficient order fulfillment with features like picking lists and ensures financial management through billing, receivables, and payables. Furthermore, it facilitates cost auditing and oversight through detailed reporting mechanisms.Accomplishments:- Spearheaded extensive refactoring of various application components, enhancing system efficiency, and optimizing performance.- Diligently identified and rectified numerous customer-reported bugs.- Conceived and implemented a robust framework from scratch, centralizing previously duplicated code, fostering a cohesive development environment, and streamlining onboarding for new developers.- Instituted significant database improvements, optimizing triggers and scripts that manage stock and reports.Pioneered features such as:- Precision scale integrations utilizing both serial and TCP/IP communications.- A sophisticated auto-updater mechanism.- A rigorous licensing control system, ensuring accurate customer invoicing and license validation.- Crafted specialized modules to accommodate custom processes for diverse production methodologies, allowing nuanced resource handling based on weight, size, or volume.

projects.title: Delphi Airbrake Lib
projects.description: This library serves as a vital tool for developers working with Delphi applications, enabling seamless integration with the Airbrake service. Its primary objective is to ensure that any errors encountered within the application are accurately reported to Airbrake. By harnessing the detailed bug reports provided by madExcept, the library guarantees that developers receive comprehensive insights into potential issues. This is particularly beneficial for identifying and rectifying issues that customers may encounter but might not directly report.Programming Languages:- DelphiSpecial Features:- Utilizes a native HTTP client implementation, ensuring the library doesn't rely on Indy.- Leverages bug reports from madExcept, providing detailed insights into application errors.- Designed to automatically capture and forward bug reports, ensuring a proactive approach to error resolution.Key Features: 1-Seamless Airbrake Integration: Facilitates real-time error reporting from Delphi applications to the Airbrake service.2-Native HTTP Client Implementation: Provides reliable communication without depending on Indy.3-Comprehensive Error Reports: Harnesses madExcept's detailed bug reports, providing a thorough understanding of any encountered issues.4-Automatic Error Capturing: The library proactively captures and forwards errors, ensuring developers are always aware of potential issues within their applications.Personal Reflection:The development of this library stemmed from the need to create a more transparent and effective error reporting mechanism for Delphi applications. Recognizing the value of the Airbrake service, this library was crafted to ensure Delphi applications could benefit from real-time error insights, leading to quicker resolutions and improved application reliability.

projects.title: Q21
projects.description: Full development of Q21 platform, a platform made to help dentists to organize its office by automating its patients appointments with custom app integration, email, sms and many more. It focus on health quality of the patients with prevention based approaches to validate the quality of the dental health of the patient. It also has features like managing the incomes and outcomes for each dentist of the clinic, dashboards, reports and many more. Web platform was develop using the follow technologies: C# with dotnet core framework using MVC, PostgreSql database, background tasks done using hangfire, mailgun email gateway integration, sms integration, realtime chat written in javascript using firebase, API develop to integrate with Flutter application for patients. Multiplatform application compatible with Android and iOS was develop using: Flutter with Firebase and API integrations to web platform, everything true secure connection and using a api token based authentication.

projects.title: Inte Map Web
projects.description: An interactive online portal tailored for event promoters. This portal served as a digital showcase for event maps, complete with search functionalities and advertising spaces specifically designed for exhibitors.The interactive map provided users with a wealth of information. They could explore videos, images, and details about exhibitors, allowing them to fully engage with the event from a distance. Additionally, the portal offered the feature of creating a personalized itinerary, enabling users to plan and customize their own tour of booths they intended to visit.For the development of this portal, I utilized a combination of HTML, jQuery, CSS, and Delphi. This blend of technologies provided a responsive and interactive user interface and a robust back-end.The system was comprised of a standard template and a dedicated map and location generating application. Reflecting on this project, I am proud of the interactive and user-centric solution I was able to provide for event promoters and attendees, transforming the way events were planned and experienced digitally.

projects.title: Inter Map
projects.description: From 2012 to 2019, I embarked on a challenging and rewarding journey of developing an innovative digital event map software solution. With a user-friendly, fully touch-screen interface, this software was designed to allow visitors to navigate through an event map effortlessly. I incorporated optimized search algorithms and location services, which helped users quickly find their desired booth or service, significantly enhancing the user experience.The backbone of this high-performance software was Delphi XE2 with VCL, DevExpress, and GDIPlus. These technologies ensured the software's robustness and reliable functionality, even under high demand.The project featured two distinct systems: the Editor and the Player. I built the Editor to enable flexible customization of the map layout and precise mapping of exhibitor areas. The Player was crafted to flawlessly execute the projects developed by the Editor.I look back with great pride on this groundbreaking event mapping solution, which made the event world more accessible for users. I'm always eager to share more about this project, so feel free to reach out for more information or a demo. I'm confident that this work contributed to revolutionizing event navigation experiences during its time.

projects.title: Flutter Talks 2019 Event Organizer
projects.description: Idealization, planning, software development and event execution. This was an ambitious project that lead us to help all the flutter community in Brazil to grow sharing their expertise with new ones. Our main objective with this project was to share and spread the knowledge of using Flutter Framework from Google across the county.All the technology used in this project was self developed since the landing page, backend software, payment gateway integration, checkin software, analysis report and everything else.The event was a huge success, we have over three hundred participants with seventeen talks over the day and sponsored by four companies that believed in us.

projects.title: Software VRU
projects.description: Development of a software tool utilized for recording telephone calls. This software consisted of two systems working together. The first was the hidden recording system, which was automatically initiated with the operating system. This system recorded all phone calls using the computer's sound card and a specific capture device connected to both the sound card and the telephone line.The second system was a management tool, allowing a supervisory user to review and listen to the recorded calls. This functionality was available both on the machine where the calls were recorded and from any other machine on the same network.The software was equipped with several unique features, such as DTMF detection through sound waves and the ability to save recordings in MP3 format. It also provided detailed call logs including duration, date, and time, and offered the functionality to add notes to each recording. This was particularly useful in a call center environment where operators could record details related to each finished call.The recording system was developed using Delphi 2007, while the management tool utilized AspNet. Both systems were built upon an MSSQL database. Looking back, I take great pride in having contributed to this vital tool which significantly enhanced telecommunications management and record-keeping practices.The main challenges here was processing the wave form sinals and extract all the information needed, also optimize the sound quality to use the best compression as possible without losing quality.

name: Teddy Siker
about:
I'm a full stack software engineer at Starbucks with a passion for building impactful, human-centered technology. Whether it‚Äôs quality engineering, game design, or front end work, I care about creating a measurable, positive impact for my customers, coworkers, and company.

At Starbucks, I use C#, CI/CD, and .NET to develop and maintain test automation frameworks that catch bugs early, bringing value to the business by avoiding mistakes. I also use React, HTML, and CSS to display our regression testing results in a transparent way so that everyone on our team can see the health of our systems.

No matter what I work on, I have the same goal: write code that makes people's lives easier and better.

experience.title: Software Engineer
experience.description: Automating GitHub CI/CD pipelines to run hundreds nightly regression tests across multiple Starbucks platforms.Expanding and maintaining a scalable .NET-based test automation framework using C# and Selenium, reducing manual testing time by 75% and enabling faster development.Building internal dashboards with React, HTML, and CSS to visualize regression test results via Allure Reports‚Äîenhancing visibility and understanding of test outcomes by 90% for cross-functional teams.Developing Python-based ETL scripts leveraging Smartsheet and Salesforce APIs to automate data migration‚Äîreducing manual data transfer time by 80% and increasing data integrity.Championing user experience and transparency, making technical decisions that prioritize clarity, usability, and real-world impact for internal and external users alike.Presenting technical solutions in clear, visual ways to empower teams and demystify complex systems, making engineering more approachable and inclusive.Contributing to Agile workflows, actively participating in sprint planning, retrospectives, and cross-team reviews to support a culture of continuous improvement.
experience.description_html:
Automating GitHub CI/CD pipelines to run hundreds nightly regression tests across multiple Starbucks platforms.

Expanding and maintaining a scalable .NET-based test automation framework using C# and Selenium, reducing manual testing time by 75% and enabling faster development.

Building internal dashboards with React, HTML, and CSS to visualize regression test results via Allure Reports—enhancing visibility and understanding of test outcomes by 90% for cross-functional teams.

Developing Python-based ETL scripts leveraging Smartsheet and Salesforce APIs to automate data migration—reducing manual data transfer time by 80% and increasing data integrity.

Championing user experience and transparency, making technical decisions that prioritize clarity, usability, and real-world impact for internal and external users alike.

Presenting technical solutions in clear, visual ways to empower teams and demystify complex systems, making engineering more approachable and inclusive.

Contributing to Agile workflows, actively participating in sprint planning, retrospectives, and cross-team reviews to support a culture of continuous improvement.

name: Clare Heinbaugh
position: PhD student at the University of Cambridge (Machine Learning & Human-Computer Interaction) | 2023 Marshall Scholar
about: Hello! I am a Marshall Scholar working towards a PhD in Engineering at the University of Cambridge, focused on machine learning and human-computer interaction. I recently completed an MPhil in Machine Learning and Machine Intelligence from Cambridge and a Bachelor of Science in computer science with a minor in math from William & Mary. After creating my first rock, paper, scissors app in 7th grade, I never looked back and devoted my high school and college career to taking as many computer science classes as possible and creating outside opportunities to make even more apps, websites, and scripts. Outside of coding, I enjoy rowing/coxing, cooking, sewing, improv comedy, and drinking as many chai lattes as possible.

experience.title: Deep Learning Researcher (ICLR 2023 Acceptance)
experience.description: I worked with Professor Shao and another W&M undergraduate to use federated learning (FL) for effective distributed learning across independent devices while maintaining the privacy of user data. I wrote most of the code and proposed the novel security method used to enhance our proposed improvement to one-shot data-free FL. Our research was accepted to the International Conference on Learning Representations (ICLR) 2023, one of the top conferences on deep learning in the world. I am grateful to the Stamps 1693 Scholars program for supporting this research.

experience.title: Technologist Intern

experience.title: Developer Student Club Project Lead
experience.description: I founded the Google Developer Student Club at William & Mary to bridge the gap between computer science and other disciplines. I have led dozens of workshops teaching game app design, web development, cloud-based technologies, and more over the past three years to anywhere from 15 to 40 participants a week. I have also led teams consulting for everything from on-campus organizations to international non-profits, including: ‚Ä¢  Key Biodiversity Areas (2022)‚Ä¢  Alliance for Peacebuilding and Data Science for Sustainable Development (Fall 2021)‚Ä¢  Alpha Phi Omega (APO) at W&M (Spring 2021)‚Ä¢ MindVersity (Fall 2020)‚Ä¢ Center for Geospatial Analysis at W&M (Spring 2019)From these projects and others I helped find, we have published multiple apps for both iOS and Android, created multiple websites, and even published a paper.

experience.title: International COMAP Competition Winner
experience.description: According to the COMAP website, "The Interdisciplinary Contest in Modeling (ICM), is an extension of the Mathematical Contest in Modeling (MCM). It is designed to develop and advance interdisciplinary problem-solving skills as well as competence in written communication." I participated in this competition on a team of three against over 26,000 other teams. We wrote an applied mathematics paper in 5 days analyzing song data from Spotify using a variety of tools including graph theory and neural networks. I was proud to place in the top four teams overall, win sponsor awards, and have my work published in The UMAP Journal of Undergraduate Mathematics and Its Applications.

experience.title: Computer science consultant
experience.description: This is a project for the William and Mary Center for Geospatial Analysis. The code which is linked here counts the black Cormorant birds in the image. The code begins by dividing the inputted image into smaller 100 pixel by 100 pixel sub images. Then it increases the contrast, recolors the dark pixels (likely birds) black then red. The birds that are counted are recolored blue. The number of birds in each sub image are added to get the total number of birds in the original image.

name: Mahesh Acharya
position: App Developer and Circuit Designer | Electrical Engineering and Computer Science
about:
As a diligent app developer and circuit designer at UC Berkeley's , my focus is crafting user-centered security solutions. Our recent initiative, Project SMASH, tackles car theft with innovative technology, demonstrating my commitment to addressing real-world challenges. The President's Gold Volunteer Service Award showcases my dedication to service and community impact.

Currently pursuing an engineering degree at UC Berkeley, I am further honing my skills in C++, CSS, and HTML. My goal is to transition from a tech enthusiast to a creator of groundbreaking technologies. Collaborating with a diverse team, we are at the forefront of designing systems that enhance societal well-being.

experience.title: UC Berkeley Transfer Pre-Engineering Program (TPREP)
experience.description: Title: App Developer and Circuit designer, Team SMASH - Car Security SolutionCompany: UC Berkeley Transfer Pre-Engineering Program (TPREP), University of California, BerkeleyDuration: July 11,2023 - July 27, 2023Description:Collaborated with a talented team of engineers in the UC Berkeley TPREP to address the prevalent issue of car break-ins in San Francisco.Conducted extensive research to identify the root causes of the issue, including the speed, slipperiness, scale, and streak nature of break-ins.Developed a comprehensive car security system, Project SMASH, designed with the user at the center of the security network.Key achievements of Project SMASH included:Evidence Documentation: Automatic video evidence saving to simplify insurance processes.Notification: Real-time alerting of potential break-in threats to nearby app users.Authorities Coordination: Immediate police notification for rapid response.Parking Safety Meter & Risk Score Calculation: Provided guidance to residents and tourists for safe parking.Impact of Project SMASH:Potentially reduced car break-ins by 48% and saved victims $9.6 million yearly in San Francisco.User-centric design aimed to make San Francisco safer for its residents and tourists.Other experiences included:Worked collaboratively with law enforcement and insurance stakeholders and interviewed victims for real-world applicability.Presented a live demo of the device in action and demonstrated a seamless website integration for parking risk score calculation.Overall Reflection:Gained valuable experience in innovation, collaboration, and learning, all while striving for social impact.Understood the complex nature of car break-ins and created a streamlined solution for car safety.Enriched my engineering skills and learned to think creatively in problem-solving.
experience.description_html:
Title: App Developer and Circuit designer, Team SMASH - Car Security Solution

Company: UC Berkeley Transfer Pre-Engineering Program (TPREP), University of California, Berkeley

Duration: July 11,2023 - July 27, 2023

Description:
Collaborated with a talented team of engineers in the UC Berkeley TPREP to address the prevalent issue of car break-ins in San Francisco.
Conducted extensive research to identify the root causes of the issue, including the speed, slipperiness, scale, and streak nature of break-ins.
Developed a comprehensive car security system, Project SMASH, designed with the user at the center of the security network.


Key achievements of Project SMASH included:
Evidence Documentation: Automatic video evidence saving to simplify insurance processes.
Notification: Real-time alerting of potential break-in threats to nearby app users.
Authorities Coordination: Immediate police notification for rapid response.
Parking Safety Meter & Risk Score Calculation: Provided guidance to residents and tourists for safe parking.

Impact of Project SMASH:
Potentially reduced car break-ins by 48% and saved victims $9.6 million yearly in San Francisco.
User-centric design aimed to make San Francisco safer for its residents and tourists.
Other experiences included:
Worked collaboratively with law enforcement and insurance stakeholders and interviewed victims for real-world applicability.
Presented a live demo of the device in action and demonstrated a seamless website integration for parking risk score calculation.


Overall Reflection:
Gained valuable experience in innovation, collaboration, and learning, all while striving for social impact.
Understood the complex nature of car break-ins and created a streamlined solution for car safety.
Enriched my engineering skills and learned to think creatively in problem-solving.

experience.title: NASA L'Space Academy
experience.description: Title: Project Team Member ( Lead Scientist ), Virtual Lunar Mission DesignCompany: NASA - National Aeronautics and Space Administration L'Space Academy Duration: January 26,2021 - May 22 ,2022Description:As part of my role at NASA L'Space Academy  as a led scientist  , I had the privilege of contributing to the development of a virtual mission aimed at in-situ resource detection on the moon. Working in a virtual environment, our diverse team collaborated to prepare a comprehensive Preliminary Design Review while adhering to a specific budget and timeline.Here are the highlights of my experience:Played an instrumental role in assisting a team of students in developing a virtual mission for in-situ resource detection on the moon.Collaborated effectively within a diverse team to create a Preliminary Design Review, ensuring alignment with the given budget and timeline.Gained extensive knowledge on mission protocols and design aspects directly from industry professionals, fostering my development for future workforce engagement.Enhanced my collaborative, design and strategic planning skills within a virtual working environment.This experience with NASA not only provided me with a solid understanding of mission protocols and lunar resource detection but also shaped my approach towards collaborative teamwork and problem-solving in a high-stakes, virtual environment.
experience.description_html:
Title: Project Team Member ( Lead Scientist ), Virtual Lunar Mission Design

Company: NASA - National Aeronautics and Space Administration L'Space Academy

Duration: January 26,2021 - May 22 ,2022

Description:

As part of my role at NASA L'Space Academy as a led scientist , I had the privilege of contributing to the development of a virtual mission aimed at in-situ resource detection on the moon. Working in a virtual environment, our diverse team collaborated to prepare a comprehensive Preliminary Design Review while adhering to a specific budget and timeline.

Here are the highlights of my experience:
Played an instrumental role in assisting a team of students in developing a virtual mission for in-situ resource detection on the moon.
Collaborated effectively within a diverse team to create a Preliminary Design Review, ensuring alignment with the given budget and timeline.
Gained extensive knowledge on mission protocols and design aspects directly from industry professionals, fostering my development for future workforce engagement.
Enhanced my collaborative, design and strategic planning skills within a virtual working environment.
This experience with NASA not only provided me with a solid understanding of mission protocols and lunar resource detection but also shaped my approach towards collaborative teamwork and problem-solving in a high-stakes, virtual environment.

about:
I'm a junior at UC Berkeley, interested in the tech industry. As a dual Computer Science and Business Administration major, I'm intrigued by the factors affecting consumer activity today. What makes one product or service more appealing than the next? How can this knowledge be leveraged to increase key sales metrics?

As such, I've undertaken many courses in the intersection of business, software engineering, and artificial intelligence. Now, I'd like to put that experience to good use, building and scaling tomorrow's best and brightest companies.

name: Michael Eugene Ng
position: UC Berkeley M.E.T. (EECS + Business) | Developer @ Codebase | ML @ DSO National Laboratories | DSTA Scholar
about:
I'm an undergraduate at UC Berkeley pursuing a double degree in Electrical Engineering & Computer Sciences (EECS) and Business Administration in the Berkeley M.E.T. program, under a merit-based, full-ride scholarship.

I am deeply passionate about technology, and aspire to build meaningful things and solve complex problems. My experience includes designing innovative deep learning algorithms, stochastic modeling, and integrating machine learning into classical frameworks to surpass industry standards. I have worked on projects in the fields of Generative AI, Full-Stack Development, Use Cases for 5G Systems, and Machine Learning and Computer Vision in image classification. 

As the co-founder of two tutoring initiatives, I enjoy sharing my knowledge with others, and relish the opportunity to learn new perspectives from them. My firm belief in a strong work-ethic underpins my aspiration to tackle grand challenges, solve global issues, and build systems that effect meaningful change. 

Aside from these interests, I love spending time with my family and friends, playing golf and tennis, or watching movies.

experience.title: Founding Software Engineer
experience.description: I started part-time during college, where I built support for Go in our SDK generator. During this time, we began to serve and build SDKs for serious, API-first companies you recognize, like OpenAI, Anthropic, Cloudflare, Lithic, Mux, Modern-Treasury, Increase, Finch, etc.Now I'm on full-time as the second Founding Engineer, depending on the way you count. I advocated for and led the initial implementation on the "SDK Studio", which helps users design their own SDKs on a web UI.Of course, being in a startup, I worked on other parts in a lot of different places, such as improving our CI system, creating our landing-site animation, various improvements in all SDK languages, profiling and improving codegen performance, email automation, Terraform support, and much, much, more.
experience.description_html:
I started part-time during college, where I built support for Go in our SDK generator. During this time, we began to serve and build SDKs for serious, API-first companies you recognize, like OpenAI, Anthropic, Cloudflare, Lithic, Mux, Modern-Treasury, Increase, Finch, etc.

Now I'm on full-time as the second Founding Engineer, depending on the way you count. I advocated for and led the initial implementation on the "SDK Studio", which helps users design their own SDKs on a web UI.

Of course, being in a startup, I worked on other parts in a lot of different places, such as improving our CI system, creating our landing-site animation, various improvements in all SDK languages, profiling and improving codegen performance, email automation, Terraform support, and much, much, more.

experience.title: Student Researcher
experience.description: With a lot of mentorship from Vighnesh Iyer, I helped build SimCommand, a library for writing fast multithreaded testbenches in Scala. SimCommand was intended to be fast and ergonomic. Ultimately we achieved a 100-200x performance uplift compared to chiseltest, which is used to test circuits written in CHISEL3, an open-source hardware description language.
experience.description_html:
With a lot of mentorship from Vighnesh Iyer, I helped build SimCommand, a library for writing fast multithreaded testbenches in Scala.

SimCommand was intended to be fast and ergonomic. Ultimately we achieved a 100-200x performance uplift compared to chiseltest, which is used to test circuits written in CHISEL3, an open-source hardware description language.

experience.title: Software Engineer
experience.description: I took over the web platform for the cloud-connected Point-of-Sale iPad app, which gave stores a way to track their sales and manage a fleet of PoS devices across multiple stores.Users were able to do data analysis through an embedded flex-table, configure options for their Store, pay for the service, and create loyalty and incentive programs through the web app. I led the design rework (although it's different again now) as well as work on an animated landing page that managed to have rich animations in just 2MB of network transfer through careful keyframing and clever javascript.
experience.description_html:
I took over the web platform for the cloud-connected Point-of-Sale iPad app, which gave stores a way to track their sales and manage a fleet of PoS devices across multiple stores.

Users were able to do data analysis through an embedded flex-table, configure options for their Store, pay for the service, and create loyalty and incentive programs through the web app. I led the design rework (although it's different again now) as well as work on an animated landing page that managed to have rich animations in just 2MB of network transfer through careful keyframing and clever javascript.

name: Krystal Karman
about:
When I was little, the internet was still an unknown and burgeoning realm of possibilities. MySpace was the most popular form of social media, and Neopets was one of the biggest games out there. As soon as I was old enough to play on my parents' laptops, I was enthralled, amazed, and overall plainly terrified of the internet. It was a big-wide world inside such a tiny machine, and it was beautiful but so intimidating. Of course, as a computer technician and the owner of a cloud-hosting business, my father swiftly taught me as much as he had time to, and as much as an eight-year-old who only wanted to play Cool Math Games could stand to learn.

In retrospect, if I told my younger self that I would be a software engineer and that I would be a part of the people who made the internet a more interesting place to be, I definitely wouldn't have believed it (I mean, it's just so cool!). And I certainly wouldn't have believed that I became a part of various projects, such as a machine learning lab that uses software to develop machine learning solutions, or that I coauthored a research paper on software development and Agile, or that I'm now working for a company that makes software for event-based companies, but I have! And I like to think that the younger me would be proud of that.

My goal is to continually develop my skillset in new and sometimes serendipitous ways to make a true and good impact in the world. I hope to continue my education in graduate school to continue to bring these new skills back to my future employer.

positions.subtitle: California Baptist University
positions.description: I was recruited for this role by a professor to be one of the founding members of the CBU Applied Machine Learning Lab (CAMML, formerly the CBU Cloud Computing Lab). CAMML produces online applications for both internal and external contractors utilizing software such as AWS, while fostering a self-directed, yet collaborative, learning environment. In this role, my goal has been to develop my skillset while producing viable projects and research, which has included research on a subset of Agile, coined the "Coalition Digital Design Framework."

name: Tyler Szeto
position: Who says you need to finish college?
about:
Open source hobbyist, working on open-source projects when not being consumed by day-job. Interests in Open-Source side of things fall into super-resolution, having made minor open source contributions by inventing and maintaining dandere2x. 

More professional work falls under data science in applications relating to research and development.

experience.title: Software Engineer
experience.description: Software Engineering with a focus on data science and research and development. Software Engineering Contributions:- Lead developer for the MockingBird project, Open Raven's tool for benchmarking data-classification software. Open Sourced Mockingbird under the APACHE-2.0 license. Installable using `pip3 install mockingbird`.- Employing machine learning where appropriate to coordinate and design automated testing environments for verifying performance and comparing of different software builds. - Designing software architecture aimed at enabling other developers to quickly answer internal software questions with data science-driven development. - Engineering build pipelines to automate build processes in various software components to reduce development risk. Research Oriented Contributions:- Using mathematical models to quantify and measure changes as well as measuring risk when evaluating changes made to different components of the Open Raven platform. - Relevant mathematics include conceptualizing Monte Carlo simulations to measure expected results of software, statistics when making data-driven decisions of product design, graph theory for software optimization, and machine learning for supervised learning.
experience.description_html:
Software Engineering with a focus on data science and research and development.

Software Engineering Contributions:

- Lead developer for the MockingBird project, Open Raven's tool for benchmarking data-classification software. Open Sourced Mockingbird under the APACHE-2.0 license. Installable using `pip3 install mockingbird`.

- Employing machine learning where appropriate to coordinate and design automated testing environments for verifying performance and comparing of different software builds.

- Designing software architecture aimed at enabling other developers to quickly answer internal software questions with data science-driven development.

- Engineering build pipelines to automate build processes in various software components to reduce development risk.

Research Oriented Contributions:

- Using mathematical models to quantify and measure changes as well as measuring risk when evaluating changes made to different components of the Open Raven platform.

- Relevant mathematics include conceptualizing Monte Carlo simulations to measure expected results of software, statistics when making data-driven decisions of product design, graph theory for software optimization, and machine learning for supervised learning.

recommendations: Ashwin Poojary ‚ÄúMegan Du interned in the Ubiquitous Streaming Platform Services SRE team which manages all the Apache Kafka and other Pub-Sub services at Twitter. Specifically, she did a fantastic job on creating a complex service to increase the flexibility in triggering any event, and executing different actions based on webhooks. This reduced the delay in remediation of alerts through automation. This includes design, documentation, coding, implementation, testing and deployment of the service with her mentors. This required the knowledge of Python and Go languages as well as conceptual understanding of webhooks and how large scale production services work.
